entry.title: Security & Risk Management
entry.content:
Security Objectives

CIA Triad
  • Confidentiality
  • Integrity
  • Availiability
Parkerian Hexad objectives
  • Confidentiality
  • Integrity
  • Availiability
  • Authenticity
  • Possession (Control)
  • Utility
McCumber Cube

  • security goals: CIA

  • information states: transimission, storage, processing

  • counter measures: technology, people, policy&practice

Functional perspective of security

What should the system do?

Assurance perspective of security

How do we ensure that they are achieved? Controls â€¦

Common Criteria (CC)

Basis for evaluation of security propertys of IT products; standard for IT security evaluation

Common set of requirements for security functionality and assurance measures (IT security requirements)

Permits comparability between results of independent security evaluations

Useful guide for: development, evaluation, procurement

shortcomings
  • consuming time and money
  • assurance is limited to TOE
  • minor changes in design/implement will make products invalid

Quantitative Risk Analysis

ALE

SLE (Single loss expectancy) = AV(Asset value)*EF(Explosure factor)

ALE(Annualized loss expectancy) = SLE*ARO(Annual rate of occurence)

shortcommings

  • We cannot distinguish high-frequency, low-impact events from low frequency, high-impact events based on such a single simplified number

  • False sense of accuracy

Challenges
  • different strategies will have different cash flow
  • secondary effects, intangible assets
  • a lot of guess work

Actualizing risk analysis

Attack Trees

Qualify an attack in different dimensions

  • leaf nodes: attack initiation

  • root node: attack goal

  • and: conjuct to achieve the goal

  • or: different ways to achieve the goal

Attack Trees Can
  • be qualified with attributes(time, money, probability)
  • made as detailed as possible
  • identify the perferred attack vectors
Fault Tree Analysis (FTA)

FTA is a general purpose technique used for system reliability and safety engineering, risk assessment

  • an undesirable system state

  • arrived at using Boolean logic combining series of lower-level events

Event Tree Analysis (ETA)

Lays a path for accessing probability of various outcomes (in a single initiating event)

Failure Mode & Effect Analysis

Review as many components/subsystems as possible to identify failure modes, their causes and effects

RPN

Risk probability number (RPN) = prob * det * sev

  • prob (prob that the failure will occur)

  • det (prob that the failure will not be detected)

  • sev (damage that the failure mode may cause; severity)

Controls

According to purpose
  • preventive (authenticate)
  • detective (detect)
  • corrective (backup)
According to nature
  • physical (who can access data center)
  • procedual (response process)
  • technical (authentication)
  • legal & regulatory / compliance (laws)
Designing Controls
Layered Defence
  • Apply Supplementary Controls
  • Independent Controls (2FA)
Defence in Depth

  • Defence in depth requires multi-layered defence

  • strategy: People, Technology, Operations

Vulnerabilities can be created in

Design, Implementation, Configureation

3 best practices for data backup

  • regular and frequency backup
  • regular testing
  • encrypt

Information Security

Cybersecurity & Infosec Differences
  • Infosec protects data across all mediums, Cybersecurity protects data in cyberspace
  • Cybersecurity protects non-information based assets
  • cybersecurity: Antivirus software, firewall
  • infosec: Encrypt data, providing security awareness training
Information Risk Management (Information Security)

Prioritize resource allocation

Given limited budget & no perfect security, minimize loss/damage

Information Security Continuous Monitoring (ISCM)

  • tier-1: high level governance issues (risk)

  • tier-2: core missions/business processes

  • tier-3: information system perspective

Sarbanes-Oxley Act

  • CEO and CFO must certify that reports are accurance and complete
  • Assessment must be reviewed and judged by an outside auditing firm

Personal Data Protect Act (PDPA)

Personal data protection commission (PDPC) organizations are required to:

  • implement policies and practices to protect personal data
  • data protection officer (DPO) oversee the data protection responsibilities

NIST (Engineering Principles for IT Security)

initation, develop/acquisition, implement, operate/maintain, disposal

Factors leading to enlarged attack surface

connectivity, complexity, extensibility

Business Impact Analysis (BIA)

  1. identify critical things (products, processes, services) that need to be restore, meet its critical needs and statisfy regulations
  2. identify activities that support critical things
  3. assest impact overtime of not performing activities
  4. set prioritized timeframes (eg. maximus tolerable downtime)
  5. identify dependencies (includes 3-rd)

Business Continuity Planning (BCP)

  • Conduct BIA and RA (establish business recovery prorities, timescale&minimum requirements)
  • BC Strategy Formulation (options for meeting business recovery prorities, timescale&minimum requirements)
  • BCP Production (plans, organizations, detailed action task lists)
  • BCP Testing
  • BC Awareness
  • Ongoing BCP Maintenance

Disaster Recover Plan

Plan activation
  • triage
  • notification
  • escalation
  • damage assessment
  • declaring a disaster
  • mobilization of response team
Disaster Recover Plan and Cyber Incident Response Plan
DRP (recover)

Actives after major systems disruptions with long-term effects

To recover and reestablish functionalities

CIRP (mitigating impact)

Masticate and isolate affected systems

To minimize loss of information

Overall Planning & Management

Emergency Response
  • Time critical
  • Initial control of emergency situation
  • Save human life
  • Stabilizing, security, damage assessment
Crisis Management
  • Strategic direction/Policy issues
  • Crisis communications
  • External liaison
  • Service recovery coordination
Bussiness Recovery
  • Phased Recovery of business-critical process/servies
  • Disaster Recovery

PDCA cycle

A manage method for control/improvement of process/products

  • Plan (establish)
  • Do (implement)
  • Check (monitor, review & audit)
  • Act (maintain, improve)

Terms

non-conformity

non-fulfilled of a requirement

policy

overall intention and direction as formally expressed by management

risk

effect of uncertainty on objectives
